description: In this introductory activity, students investigate the phenomena of wildfires in the western part of the United States. They explore real-world data on the frequency of wildfires and the number of acres burned over time. Students connect their ideas about the trends in the data to what might be causing the fluctuations. Students also begin to consider what makes wildfires hazardous and how they impact people and their communities.
name: Feelin' Hot, Hot, Hot!

embeddables.content:
Wildfires are a natural phenomenon that happen every year all around the world. Sometimes wildfires can grow very large and out of control. They can spread close to places where people work and live. As a wildfire burns and spreads, the skies turn red and are filled with smoke. Wildfires can be deadly to the people, ecosystems, and animals in their path. 

Scientists use models to study wildfires. In this module, you will use a wildfire model to investigate the factors that affect wildfires in order to answer the framing question:

How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years? 

To answer this question, you first need to learn about where wildfires start and how they spread, what hazards wildfires bring, who is at risk from wildfire, and how these hazards impact people and their communities.

As the world experiences extreme heat waves and droughts with more frequency due to climate change, firefighters will continue to struggle to bring these fires under control. These fires sharpen the call to take climate change more seriously and explore the role it plays in the development of these natural hazards. Climate change plays an important role; warmer temperatures means drier vegetation, which acts as perfect kindling for fires. Hot, dry winds also help spread wildfire. It is the goal of this module to help students explore how the different components in the fire triangle-- oxygen, heat, fuel --are amplified as a result of a changing climate. In addition, we will provide students with the opportunity to consider the factors that transform a natural phenomenon into a natural hazard. Students will explore the risks, hazards, and impacts of wildfires on people and their communities. They will also consider environmental impacts to important ecosystems. In line with the NGSS (see Wildfire Module Standards Alignment), this module engages students in the use of evidence gathered from exploration with the Wildfire Explorer, a model we developed to investigate variables that influence the spread and impacts of a wildfire on communities and environments in its path. pages.name: Are wildfires burning more now than in the past?

embeddables.content:
Wildfires occur all over the world. Recently, in the United States, there have been some of the most intense and damaging wildfires of all time. Are these large fires the new normal? Will we continue to see wildfires like this over the next few decades? Scientists are thinking about these questions and this module will help you think about these questions, too.

Some areas are more prone to wildfire than others. In the United States, they occur most frequently in the western states like California, Montana, and Idaho. The map below highlights the states that are considered part of the western U.S. The graph shows the number of acres that wildfires have burned in this region. Examine the graph and answer the questions below.

embeddables.caption: The number of acres burned by wildfires in the western United States every year from 1915-2015.

embeddables.content:
Wildfires can start naturally by lightning. However, about 85% of wildfires are accidentally started by people! Faulty electrical wires, campfires, and cigarettes often provide the spark that starts a fire. Below is a map of wildfires that were burning in December 2017 in Southern California.

One reason why these fires were so dangerous was because they were close to major cities. Below is a map of Los Angeles County. Around 10 million people live in this part of California and were at risk when the fires approached. Los Angeles County is very diverse, with people of many different backgrounds, ages, and income levels.

embeddables.caption: Location of Southern California wildfires in December of 2017.

embeddables.content:
Scientists use many different tools and models to monitor wildfires as they form and spread. Predicting where and when a wildfire could reach a city can help people and communities prepare for the hazards that wildfires bring.

When a wildfire comes near an area where people work or live, that area is considered at risk of the damage that wildfire can bring.

A **wildfire is a natural phenomenon**. It is an unplanned fire.
A **wildfire becomes a natural hazard when it occurs near people and causes damage to property and human life**. 

It is important to note that naturally occurring wildfires benefit native vegetation, animals and ecosystems that have evolved with fires. The module will address this concept in later activities.

embeddables.content:
You have now seen that there is an upward trend in the number of acres wildfires burn. Scientists agree! They have noticed this trend and are studying the wildfires of the past in order to help predict wildfires in the future.

In this module, you will learn more about the scientific factors that influence wildfires and consider the risks and impacts of wildfires to people and their communities both now and in the years to come.

{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"An important concept that forms the basis and motivation for this module is the understanding of hazards, impacts, and risk. These three words will be repeated throughout the module. Students should practice using these terms and distinguish between them. 

**A hazard is anything that has the potential to harm people or the environment.** The two hazards of wildfires are smoke and fire.

**An impact is an outcome of a hazard.** Impacts can be positive or negative. Negative impacts of fire are buildings burning down, ecosystems being destroyed, and many others. Positive impacts include new vegetation growth and elimination of invasive species.

**Risk is the likelihood of a hazard to cause a specific impact.** For example, southern California is at a high risk (degree of likelihood) of fire (the hazard) burning down homes (impact) when there is severe drought in the area. Risk involves some level of uncertainty with prediction because we can never exactly know what is going to happen.","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"discussionPoints","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"*This is a great place to stop and elicit students’ initial ideas about the hazards and risks of wildfires.* This activity has introduced the socio-economic issues that arise when communities prepare for wildfires and other natural disasters. This topic will be visited again later in the module. However, because of the complexity of this issue the module will only address a few of these issues. At this point, eliciting students’ initial ideas about risks to different populations is important. Both preparing for wildfires (buying supplies and staying put) and evacuating (access to reliable transportation and having a safe place to go) can be expensive. Asking questions like, “Why is it more difficult for older people or sick people to prepare for a wildfire?” and "Why is it more difficult for people from low socioeconomic communities to evacuate during a wildfire?" will generate rich class discussions. We suggest you use an off-line tool called a Summary Table to record student ideas. Summary Tables can be used individually by students to track their thinking as they progress toward an explanatory model of the phenomenon and guiding question: **How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years? ** A Summary Table can also be used to record student ideas in a public place, such as a poster or a projected online document shared at the front of the room.
